Description: 'Kilga' (jar stand for water) made of marble with carved decoration consisting of palmettes, fantastical beasts, lions and an Arabic inscription.
Curator's comments: The Qur’an repeatedly instructs Muslims to provide water for the thirsty, and this kilga may have been commissioned by an individual as an act of piety to provide refreshment to passers-by in a public setting. There are many examples of kilgas in different collections. One was offered through auction at Paris on 20 December 2011 (Christie's p.13, lot 26).
Bibliographic references: Fluck et al. 2015 / Egypt: Faith after the Pharaohs (p.208)
Akbarnia et al 2018 / The Islamic World: a History in Objects (p.109, fig.4)
